channel.title: Latest PHMSA Hazardous Materials Incident Reports, for FL
channel.description: The latest Form 5800.1 hazardous material reports submitted to the Department of Transportation and posted online by the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration, for FL

item.title: Report X-2023120634
item.description:
Report X-2023120634

Identified by scraper @ 2024-01-09T06:14:28+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-12-08
  • City: OCALA
  • State: FL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: Package was found wet & had gasoline scent. Upon inspection 1 Pulsar PGDA70BiSCO 7250-watts inverter generator was found with gasoline inside. Gas leak out of cap. A document found inside informing shipper to drain gas & oil out before shipping to location to inspect unit. DescribePack: Generator had gasoline inside. Spill gasoline out of cap. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Placed in hazmat bag lined tote.

item.title: Report E-2023120474
item.description:
Report E-2023120474

Identified by scraper @ 2024-01-03T15:12:34+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-12-15
  • City: MIAMI
  • State: FL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On December 15, 2023, one (1) 55-gallon drum containing UN1789 was damaged and released approximately two (2) gallons of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from American Compliance Technologies (ACT) to remediate the impacted site. ACT personnel utilized hand tools, absorbents, and soda ash to remediate the sulfuric acid-impacted impacted trailer floor and soil under the trailer. Crews tightened the bung and the leak stopped. Crews secured the drum upright to the trailer wall and the driver continued on to the terminal. Utilizing hand tools, the ACT crew was able to excavate the impacted soil. All impacted debris were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum that was taken by ACT.

item.title: Report E-2023120459
item.description:
Report E-2023120459

Identified by scraper @ 2024-01-03T15:12:34+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-12-07
  • City: ORLANDO
  • State: FL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Approximately half a gallon of battery acid (UN2794) was released from one forklift battery after it fell over. The release impacted the trailer and concrete. The SDS was reviewed with the terminal and after speaking to the service center manager it was determined that terminal staff are capable of cleaning the release with PPE on site. (1) 65-gallon poly drum containing battery acid, PPE, and Oil Dri was left onsite for the terminal to manage.

item.title: Report I-2023090113
item.description:
Report I-2023090113

Identified by scraper @ 2024-01-05T00:33:43+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-08-08
  • City: JACKSONVILLE
  • State: FL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: EAST PENN LOGISTICS LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Driver picked up junk industrial forklift batteries at retail store for recycling. During transit 2 of the pallets collapsed. The leak was detected at a truck stop when the driver checked his load. He noticed that 2 of the pallets failed and broke causing the batteries on the pallets to fall over and leak. The driver used soda ash (approximately 1.5 gallons) to create a dam/ berm, at the back of the trailer to prevent acid leaking out the door. He also spread some on the floor. A HazMat crew was called by corporate to assist in the clean-up. The HazMat team used speedy dry, and soda ash to clean up/ neutralize the acid inside the trailer as well as what leaked outside of the trailer on the black top. No acid had gotten into any storm drains. Once the acid was no longer leakingÂ· the trailer was moved to a local customer to help upright and reload the batteries. The HazMat team cleaned out the trailer before it was reloaded. One drum of spent acid/ soda ash was collected for disposal by the Hazmat team. Once reloaded the driver continued to East Penn Manufacturing Co. for battery recycling.
